newsitem.title: USA: US debt allocations little changed - Stone&McCarthy.
newsitem.headline: US debt allocations little changed - Stone&McCarthy.

text.p: Money managers' U.S. debt portfolios were little-changed in the week ended September 3, said a survey by Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc.
"Not much happened in this week's survey," the report said. "Activity was light and survey statistics were virtually unchanged."
The report said the survey's bear/bull index arithmetic reading fell to 4.04 from 4.16 the week before, while the asset-weighted number came in at 4.34, down from the 4.44 in the previous period.
A number above 5.00 is seen as indicating investors are mostly long on the market.
The cash/assets ratio rose to 6.72 percent from 6.62 percent.
Duration bogey held steady at 4.06 on an arithmetic basis and 4.69 on a weighted basis.
Duration bogey is the level of asset or liability duration sought in the management of a portfolio.
Duration refers to a portfolio's average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.

Twenty-eight percent of portfolio managers polled said they were planning to be active in the coming week, up from 12 percent the week before. The bear/bull index collected among those who intend to be active slipped to 5.14 from 5.33.
The Stone & McCarthy survey is conducted by the research firm weekly. It includes 25 market participants with total assets of about $100 billion, the firm said.
* Table provided by Stone and McCarthy Research Associates.
** Respondents intending to adjust portfolio in coming week.
